template.template: Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP
template.name: Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP
template.description:
The template to monitor Elasticsearch by Zabbix that work without any external scripts. It works with both standalone and cluster instances. The metrics are collected in one pass remotely using an HTTP agent. They are getting values from REST API _cluster/health, _cluster/stats, _nodes/stats requests. You can set {$ELASTICSEARCH.USERNAME} and {$ELASTICSEARCH.PASSWORD} macros in the template for using on the host level. If you use an atypical location ES API, don't forget to change the macros {$ELASTICSEARCH.SCHEME},{$ELASTICSEARCH.PORT}.
You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/399473-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-for-elasticsearch
Template tooling version used: 0.38

item.name: ES: Delayed unassigned shards
item.description: The number of shards whose allocation has been delayed by the timeout settings.

item.name: ES: Get cluster health
item.description: Returns the health status of a cluster.

item.name: ES: Get cluster stats
item.description: Returns cluster statistics.

item.name: ES: Inactive shards percentage
item.description: The ratio of inactive shards in the cluster expressed as a percentage.

item.name: ES: Number of initializing shards
item.description: The number of shards that are under initialization.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has the initializing shards
trigger.description: The cluster has the initializing shards longer than 10 minutes.

item.name: ES: Number of data nodes
item.description: The number of nodes that are dedicated to data nodes.

item.name: ES: Number of nodes
item.description: The number of nodes within the cluster.

trigger.name: ES: The number of nodes within the cluster has decreased
ES: The number of nodes within the cluster has increased

item.name: ES: Number of pending tasks
item.description: The number of cluster-level changes that have not yet been executed.

item.name: ES: Number of relocating shards
item.description: The number of shards that are under relocation.

item.name: ES: Cluster health status
item.description: Health status of the cluster, based on the state of its primary and replica shards. Statuses are: green All shards are assigned. yellow All primary shards are assigned, but one or more replica shards are unassigned. If a node in the cluster fails, some data could be unavailable until that node is repaired. red One or more primary shards are unassigned, so some data is unavailable. This can occur briefly during cluster startup as primary shards are assigned.

trigger.name: ES: Health is YELLOW
trigger.description: All primary shards are assigned, but one or more replica shards are unassigned. If a node in the cluster fails, some data could be unavailable until that node is repaired.

trigger.name: ES: Health is RED
trigger.description: One or more primary shards are unassigned, so some data is unavailable. This can occur briefly during cluster startup as primary shards are assigned.

trigger.name: ES: Health is UNKNOWN
trigger.description: The health status of the cluster is unknown or cannot be obtained.

item.name: ES: Task max waiting in queue
item.description: The time expressed in seconds since the earliest initiated task is waiting for being performed.

item.name: ES: Number of unassigned shards
item.description: The number of shards that are not allocated.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has the unassigned shards
trigger.description: The cluster has the unassigned shards longer than 10 minutes.

item.name: ES: Indices with shards assigned to nodes
item.description: The total number of indices with shards assigned to the selected nodes.

item.name: ES: Number of non-deleted documents
item.description: The total number of non-deleted documents across all primary shards assigned to the selected nodes. This number is based on the documents in Lucene segments and may include the documents from nested fields.

item.name: ES: Nodes with the data role
item.description: The number of selected nodes with the data role.

item.name: ES: Nodes with the ingest role
item.description: The number of selected nodes with the ingest role.

item.name: ES: Nodes with the master role
item.description: The number of selected nodes with the master role.

trigger.name: ES: Cluster has only two master nodes
trigger.description: The cluster has only two nodes with a master role and will be unavailable if one of them breaks.

item.name: ES: Total available size to JVM in all file stores
item.description: The total number of bytes available to JVM in the file stores across all selected nodes. Depending on OS or process-level restrictions, this number may be less than nodes.fs.free_in_byes. This is the actual amount of free disk space the selected Elasticsearch nodes can use.

item.name: ES: Total size of all file stores
item.description: The total size in bytes of all file stores across all selected nodes.

item.name: ES: Get nodes stats
item.description: Returns cluster nodes statistics.

item.name: ES: Cluster uptime
item.description: Uptime duration in seconds since JVM has last started.

item.name: ES: Service response time
item.description: Checks performance of the TCP service.

trigger.name: ES: Service response time is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.RESPONSE_TIME.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: The performance of the TCP service is very low.

item.name: ES: Service status
item.description: Checks if the service is running and accepting TCP connections.

trigger.name: ES: Service is down
trigger.description: The service is unavailable or does not accept TCP connections.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total available size
item_prototype.description: The total number of bytes available to this Java virtual machine on all file stores. Depending on OS or process level restrictions, this might appear less than fs.total.free_in_bytes. This is the actual amount of free disk space the Elasticsearch node can utilize.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total size
item_prototype.description: Total size (in bytes) of all file stores.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Number of open HTTP connections
item_prototype.description: The number of currently open HTTP connections for the node.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of HTTP connections opened
item_prototype.description: The number of HTTP connections opened for the node per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Flush latency
item_prototype.description: The average flush latency calculated from the available flush.total and flush.total_time_in_millis metrics.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Flush latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.FLUSH_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: If you see this metric increasing steadily, it may indicate a problem with slow disks; this problem may escalate and eventually prevent you from being able to add new information to your index.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent on flushing indices to disk
item_prototype.description: Total time in milliseconds spent performing flush operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of index flushes to disk
item_prototype.description: The total number of flush operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Current indexing operations
item_prototype.description: The number of indexing operations currently running.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Indexing latency
item_prototype.description: The average indexing latency calculated from the available index_total and index_time_in_millis metrics.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Indexing latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.INDEXING_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: If the latency is increasing, it may indicate that you are indexing too many documents at the same time (Elasticsearchâ€™s documentation recommends starting with a bulk indexing size of 5 to 15 megabytes and increasing slowly from there).

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent performing indexing
item_prototype.description: Total time in milliseconds spent performing indexing operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of indexing
item_prototype.description: The total number of indexing operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent throttling operations
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent throttling operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent throttling merge operations
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent throttling merge operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent throttling recovery operations
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent throttling recovery operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of index refreshes
item_prototype.description: The number of refresh operations per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent performing refresh
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent performing refresh operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Current fetch operations
item_prototype.description: The number of fetch operations currently running.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Fetch latency
item_prototype.description: The average fetch latency calculated by sampling the total number of fetches and the total elapsed time at regular intervals.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Fetch latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.FETCH_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The fetch phase should typically take much less time than the query phase. If you notice this metric consistently increasing, this could indicate a problem with slow disks, enriching of documents (highlighting the relevant text in search results, etc.), or requesting too many results.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent performing fetch
item_prototype.description: Time in milliseconds spent performing fetch operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent performing fetch
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent performing fetch operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of fetch
item_prototype.description: The total number of fetch operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of fetch
item_prototype.description: The number of fetch operations per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Current query operations
item_prototype.description: The number of query operations currently running.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Query latency
item_prototype.description: The average query latency calculated by sampling the total number of queries and the total elapsed time at regular intervals.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Query latency is too high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.QUERY_LATENCY.MAX.WARN}ms for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: If latency exceeds a threshold, look for potential resource bottlenecks, or investigate whether you need to optimize your queries.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total time spent performing query
item_prototype.description: Time in milliseconds spent performing query operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Time spent performing query
item_prototype.description: Time in seconds spent performing query operations for the last measuring span.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Total number of query
item_prototype.description: The total number of query operations.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Rate of queries
item_prototype.description: The number of query operations per second.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Amount of JVM heap committed
item_prototype.description: The amount of memory, in bytes, available for use by the heap.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Maximum JVM memory available for use
item_prototype.description: The maximum amount of memory, in bytes, available for use by the heap.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Amount of JVM heap currently in use
item_prototype.description: The memory, in bytes, currently in use by the heap.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap currently in use
item_prototype.description: The percentage of memory currently in use by the heap.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap in use is high (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.HEAP_USED.MAX.WARN}% for 1h)
trigger_prototype.description: This indicates that the rate of garbage collection isnâ€™t keeping up with the rate of garbage creation. To address this problem, you can either increase your heap size (as long as it remains below the recommended guidelines stated above), or scale out the cluster by adding more nodes.

dependency.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap in use is critical (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.HEAP_USED.MAX.CRIT}% for 1h)

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Percent of JVM heap in use is critical (over {$ELASTICSEARCH.HEAP_USED.MAX.CRIT}% for 1h)
trigger_prototype.description: This indicates that the rate of garbage collection isnâ€™t keeping up with the rate of garbage creation. To address this problem, you can either increase your heap size (as long as it remains below the recommended guidelines stated above), or scale out the cluster by adding more nodes.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Node uptime
item_prototype.description: JVM uptime in seconds.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool active threads
item_prototype.description: The number of active threads in the refresh thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool executor tasks completed
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks completed by the refresh thread pool executor.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool tasks in queue
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks in queue for the refresh thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool executor tasks rejected
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the refresh thread pool executor.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Refresh thread pool executor has the rejected tasks (for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the refresh thread pool executor is over 0 for 5m.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Search thread pool active threads
item_prototype.description: The number of active threads in the search thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Search thread pool executor tasks completed
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks completed by the search thread pool executor.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Search thread pool tasks in queue
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks in queue for the search thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Search thread pool executor tasks rejected
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the search thread pool executor.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Search thread pool executor has the rejected tasks (for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the search thread pool executor is over 0 for 5m.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Write thread pool active threads
item_prototype.description: The number of active threads in the write thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Write thread pool executor tasks completed
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks completed by the write thread pool executor.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Write thread pool tasks in queue
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks in queue for the write thread pool.

item_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Write thread pool executor tasks rejected
item_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the write thread pool executor.

trigger_prototype.name: ES {#ES.NODE}: Write thread pool executor has the rejected tasks (for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: The number of tasks rejected by the write thread pool executor is over 0 for 5m.

macro.description: Maximum of fetch latency in milliseconds for trigger expression.
Maximum of flush latency in milliseconds for trigger expression.
The maximum percent in the use of JVM heap for critically trigger expression.
The maximum percent in the use of JVM heap for warning trigger expression.
Maximum of indexing latency in milliseconds for trigger expression.
The port of the Elasticsearch host.
Maximum of query latency in milliseconds for trigger expression.
The ES cluster maximum response time in seconds for trigger expression.

trigger.expression: ({Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP:es.nodes.fs.total_in_bytes.last()}-{Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP:es.nodes.fs.available_in_bytes.last()})/({Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP:es.cluster.number_of_data_nodes.last()}-1)>{Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP:es.nodes.fs.available_in_bytes.last()}
trigger.name: ES: Cluster does not have enough space for resharding
trigger.description: There is not enough disk space for index resharding.

item.host: Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP
Template App Elasticsearch Cluster by HTTP
